title: Wyre Forest Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: P L Chadwick / Dowles Brook, Wyre Forest
images.caption: Dowles Brook, Wyre Forest. The Dowles Brook discharges into the River Severn, near Bewdley.

images.title: P L Chadwick / Forestry road, Wyre Forest
images.caption: Forestry road in the autumn of 2009. The road is used by authorised motor vehicles, mainly in connection with the forestry operations going on in this part of the forest. It also forms part of National Cycle Route 45.

images.title: P L Chadwick / Corbets Park, Wyre Forest
images.caption: This area of the forest is known as Corbets Park.

images.title: Kieron McMahon / Knowles Mill in the Wyre Forest
images.caption: Knowles Mill in the Wyre Forest. Knowles Mill is located on Dowles Brook in the ancient woodland known as Knowles Coppice.

images.title: P L Chadwick / Grass path in Wyre Forest
images.caption: Grass path in Wyre Forest. This path leads off the main forestry road and runs parallel to it.

images.title: P L Chadwick / Footpath and sign in Wyre Forest
images.caption: Footpath and sign in the forest. Since the recently created new Government quango "Natural England" was created and made responsible for most National Nature Reserves, it has been busy decorating the Wyre Forest with new signs. Here, deep in the Forest, this one has recently appeared. It is by the side of the grassed area over the pipeline route and at the point where a footpath plunges into the forest. Previously there was no sign around here

images.title: P L Chadwick / Autumnal scene in the Wyre Forest
images.caption: Autumnal scene in the forest. In late October most of the leaves are still on the trees, although many have already turned various shades of red, brown and gold. The track here is a turning off the main forestry road in this part of the forest

images.title: P L Chadwick / Forestry road in Wyre Forest
images.caption: Forestry road. This forestry road has come up from the car park by the B4194 road and is heading towards Bewdley. The dog slipped into the picture unseen. She blends in very well with the brown fern!

description: This large forest near Bewdley has miles of super cycling and walking trails to enjoy. Cyclists can enjoy the family mountain bike trail which runs along nice wide paths through the woodland. There is also a section along a disused railway line and through a Nature Reserve. The trail is waymarked with blue markers. Bikes can be hired from Bewdley Outdoors. Walkers can enjoy three waymarked walking trails of varying lengths and difficulty. On the trails you'll pass through coniferous and deciduous forest and visit the lovely Wyre Arboretum. The circular route below starts near Button Oak and follows the cycle/walk trails through the forest to Dowles. Here you can return to the start point on country lanes if you are on a bike. If on foot you may prefer to return along the lovely waterside path along Dowles Brook which runs parallel to the dismantled railway line. Near the start of the route there's the Button Oak Meadow nature reserve where you'll find some pleasant woodland trails with lots of flora and fauna. Keep your eyes peeled for wildlife like deer, squirrels and various woodland birds as you make your way through this area.
